awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Rohini Ramadas is "Dynamics on the Moduli Space of Pointed Rational Curves." The host institution for the fellowship is Harvard University, and the sponsoring scientist is Joe Harris.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Overview: Discrete dynamics is the study of the behavior of maps under iteration. It is natural to investigate not just the dynamical behavior of one map in isolation, but also the variation of dynamical behavior within families of maps - this perspective leads us to consider moduli spaces. The field of complex dynamics underwent a transformation with Douady and Hubbard's exploration of the Mandelbrot set, a beautiful fractal inside the moduli space of quadratic maps. Many new discoveries centered on the special dynamics of post-critically finite (PCF) maps and their distribution in the moduli space of rational maps. For example, PCF maps are dense in the infinitely complicated boundary of the Mandelbrot set. PCF maps have been studied from several points of view: topological and Teichmüller-theoretic, complex-analytic and measure-theoretic, arithmetic, and non-archimedean. While complex/arithmetic dynamics in general, and PCF maps in particular, have been mostly studied in dimension one, there have been many recent developments in higher dimensions. These include a discovery of Koch linking PCF maps in one dimension with PCF maps in higher dimensions via Hurwitz correspondences (HCs), which are dynamical systems acting on moduli spaces of curves. In particular, (nearly) every PCF map in dimension one arises as an isolated fixed point of some HC. 

Intellectual Merit: During this project, the PI used algebro-geometric and combinatorial aspects of moduli spaces to make new discoveries in dynamics. The PI used numerical invariants called dynamical degrees to establish relationships between the dynamical complexity of an HC (higher-dimensional dynamics) and the dynamical complexity of the associated PCF map (one-dimensional dynamics). Nguyen-Bac Dang and the PI studied the dynamics of monomial correspondences on toric varieties, and found formulas for the dynamical degrees of monomial correspondences. Patrick Ingram, Joseph Silverman and the PI pioneered the study, in higher dimension, of the PCF locus in moduli spaces of self-maps, finding that in certain cases this locus is “sparse” (unlike in the setting of 1-dimensional dynamics). Rob Silversmith and the PI developed new tools for the study of the geometry of critical-orbit-relation loci in moduli spaces of rational maps, via combinatorial compactifications of Hurwitz spaces. Using insights gleaned from the dynamics of HCs, Rob Silversmith and the PI answered representation-theoretic questions about the symmetric group action on the moduli space of curves. Emily Clader, Chiara Damiolini, Daoji Huang, Shiyue Li and the PI studied moduli spaces of orbits of cyclic actions on the Riemann sphere, establishing a combinatorial connection with the structure of complex reflection groups, as well as with a certain polyhedral complex.

 Broader Impacts: During the period of this award, the PI contributed to gender inclusivity in mathematics by co-organizing a "Graduate Workshop in Algebraic Geometry for Women and Mathematicians of Minority Genders" at Harvard and MIT, a "Women in Algebraic Geometry" workshop at ICERM, and a "Women@AGNES" event at Brown University.
